02.01.question: The V-model pays more explicit attention to ___________:

02.02.question: Bob is selecting a systems analysis and design methodology. What might be the first step?

02.02.B.choice: Researching the organizations standards and policies for 'approved' methodologies

02.02.C.choice: Do a quick 'cost/benefit' analysis on which methodology will provide the most benefits at the lowest cost

02.02.D.choice: Do an analysis on which methodology might lessen or eliminate scope creep

02.02.E.choice: Interviewing senior management as to their suggestions on methodologies

02.03.question: Most IT departments face a demand for IT projects that far exceed the ability to do them.

02.04.question: The project methodology that takes the longest to complete is Extreme Programming Methodology.

02.05.question: The most common reason for schedule and cost overruns is what?

02.05.A.choice: Adding people to a late project

02.05.C.choice: Lack of communication from project manager to project team

02.05.D.choice: Lack of support by sponsor and champion

02.06.question: System prototyping is BEST characterized as:

02.06.B.choice: A method for exploring design alternatives

02.06.D.choice: A method for stressing customer satisfaction

02.07.question: Scrum, XP and Dynamic systems development method (DSDM) are all classified as 'agile development' concepts.

02.08.question: Project teams of 12 to 15 are generally considered optimum

02.09.question: Which of the following methodologies might be most appropriate if you have a system project with: clear requirements; very familiar technologies; not all that complex; must be reliable; a somewhat longer schedule and the schedule visibility is not important?

02.10.question: If the skills required by a project cannot be met by the available project team, which would probably NOT be a reasonable solution?

02.10.A.choice: Mentor a team member (like sending a person to work on a similar project to acquire the necessary skills)

02.10.D.choice: Modify the project to use skills inherent on the project team

02.10.E.choice: Train the project team (or some of the team) on the skills needed

02.11.question: A critical success factor in project management is to do which of the following?

02.11.A.choice: Use a CASE tool to delineate requirements from work tasks

02.11.B.choice: Say "no" to all requests as they add to 'scope creep'

02.11.C.choice: Hire an outside project management consulting group

02.11.E.choice: Start with a realistic assessment of the work that needs to be done

02.12.question: Throwaway prototyping is BEST characterized as:

02.12.A.choice: A method for exploring design alternatives

02.12.E.choice: A method for stressing customer satisfaction

02.13.question: Agile development is a group of programming-centric methodologies that focus on which of the following?

02.13.A.choice: Working with a highly controversial project that may have political implications

02.14.question: Scope creep happens when new requirements are added to the project after the original project scope was defined.

02.15.question: Which of the following might result in version 1; version 2 (etc.) of a system?

02.16.question: A classic planning mistake mentioned in the textbook is having an 'overly optimistic schedule'.

02.17.question: PMP is People – Management – Project – the three components of successful project management.

02.18.question: The margin of error in cost and time estimates can be as much as 20% in the planning phase for the system proposal deliverable.

02.19.question: If you had a project with very clear requirements; familiar technologies; not super complex; reliable; a very long time schedule and where the need for schedule visibility is low – the best methodology might be Extreme programming.

02.20.question: Nate is managing a project that is behind by one month with five months to go. He should add four to six staff persons to the project to get it back up to speed.

02.21.question: TJ is coordinating a project. Which would he probably NOT use to avoid conflicts?

02.21.B.choice: Communicate the business value to the team

02.21.C.choice: Clearly defining plans for the project

02.21.D.choice: Encourage a competitive edge between team members

02.21.E.choice: Look at other projects and priorities and see how that might impact the project

02.22.question: Interpersonal skills for a project manager might be important when:

02.22.B.choice: Using the V-model variation of the Waterfall Methodology.

02.22.C.choice: Working with a highly controversial project that may have political implications

02.23.question: Which of the following would BEST describe "system reliability"?

02.23.A.choice: The aspect of how quickly the system can be developed and implemented

02.23.B.choice: The aspect of how complex the system must be

02.23.C.choice: The aspect of using technologies that analysts and developers are familiar with

02.23.D.choice: The aspect of what the business side really wants the system to do

02.23.E.choice: The aspect of how accurate the system must be (such as medical equipment or for games)

02.24.question: Rapid Application Development is a collection of methodologies that include all of the following except:

02.25.question: Throwaway Prototyping balances the benefits of well-thought-out analysis and design phases with the advantages of using prototypes to refine key issues before a system is built.

02.26.question: Agile Development stresses analysis, modeling and documentation over programming.

02.27.question: A classic planning mistake mentioned in the textbook is motivating employees with financial rewards instead of recognition and genuine thanks.

02.28.question: Extreme programming requires a great deal of discipline and it is recommended for:

02.29.question: Extreme Programming (XP) stresses customer satisfaction and teamwork.

02.30.question: Which of the following methodologies might be most appropriate if you have a system project with: somewhat unclear requirements; somewhat unfamiliar technologies; that is complex; reasonably reliable; a short time schedule and high schedule visibility?

02.31.question: The corporate IT department carefully needs to prioritize, select and manage a portfolio of projects.

02.32.question: A critical success factor for project management is to start with a realistic assessment of the work that needs to be accomplished.

02.33.question: Suggestions for motivation might include all of these EXCEPT:

02.33.C.choice: Giving all team members the same bonus on a project

02.33.D.choice: Reward those with outstanding quality and effort

02.34.question: Which of the following methodologies might be most appropriate if you have a system project with: unclear requirements; very familiar technologies; not all that complex; reasonably reliable; a short time schedule and the schedule visibility is somewhat important?

02.35.question: CIO is an acronym for "Chief Information Officer".

02.36.question: Project Managers must be certified as PMP (Project Management Professionals)

02.37.question: Which of the following is not a project characteristic that will affect the methodology selection decision?

02.38.question: Which of the following methodologies might be most appropriate if you have a system project with: unclear user requirements; unfamiliar technologies; very complex; must be reliable; a short to medium time schedule and the schedule visibility is somewhat important?

02.39.question: The main difference between the Parallel Development Methodology and the Iterative Development Methodology is that:

02.39.A.choice: The Parallel Development Methodology will have various releases (like version 1.0; 2.0, etc.) and the Iterative will not

02.39.B.choice: The Iterative Methodology will create various models or prototypes with user involvement before setting on design concepts and the Parallel Methodology will not

02.39.C.choice: The Parallel Methodology will have subprojects and the Iterative Methodology will have various releases

02.39.D.choice: The Iterative Methodology will break the system project into sub-projects for analysis, design and implementation and then merge them into a final system and the Parallel will not

02.39.E.choice: The Parallel Methodology will create various models or prototypes with user involvement before setting on design concepts and the Iterative will not

02.40.question: Which is a true statement about IT projects?

02.40.A.choice: Project Managers must be certified as PMP (Project Management Professionals)

02.40.B.choice: Project teams of 12 to 15 are generally considered optimum

02.40.C.choice: Most IT departments face a demand for IT projects that far exceed the ability to do them.

02.40.D.choice: Project estimates tend to have a built-in buffer of time

02.40.E.choice: The majority of projects taken on by IT departments are not strategic to the business

02.42.question: Garrett has been told by management that his project MUST be completed on time. His best estimates are more than two weeks after the absolute deadline. Which technique could he use to get a functional system on time?

02.43.question: The Iterative approach of the RAD methodology breaks the overall project into a series of release versions.

02.44.question: The majority of projects taken on by IT departments are not strategic to the business

02.45.question: Which of the following methodologies takes the longest to complete all the SDLC steps?

02.46.question: The Waterfall Methodology breaks the overall project into a series of release versions.

02.47.question: Which is NOT suggested for IT development projects?

02.47.A.choice: Projects need to give a positive return on investment within four years

02.47.B.choice: Projects need to give value to the business

02.47.D.choice: Projects need to be carefully managed

02.47.E.choice: Projects need to be carefully selected

02.48.question: The Throwaway Prototyping methodology is especially good for exploring design alternatives.

02.49.question: Either systems prototyping or throwaway prototyping are generally a good methodology choice when the project has unclear user requirements.

02.50.question: Which of the following methodologies might be most appropriate if you have a system project with: clear requirements; very familiar technologies; not all that complex; reasonably reliable; a very long time schedule, and the schedule visibility is not important?

02.51.question: Which of the following would BEST describe "system complexity"?

02.51.A.choice: The aspect of using technologies that analysts and developers are familiar with

02.51.B.choice: The aspect of what the business side really wants the system to do

02.51.C.choice: The aspect of how accurate the system must be (such as medical equipment or for games)

02.51.D.choice: The aspect of how intricate and difficult the system must be

02.51.E.choice: The aspect of how quickly the system can be developed and implemented

02.52.question: Which would generally NOT be taken into consideration for project portfolio management in an organization?

02.52.B.choice: The number of high risk projects

02.52.E.choice: The number of financially feasible projects

02.53.question: In most IT departments, the demand for IT projects is generally about the same as the department's ability to supply them.

02.54.question: The project methodology that takes the longest to complete is the Waterfall Development Methodology.

02.55.question: Which of the following methodologies might be most appropriate if you have a system project with: unclear user requirements; unfamiliar technologies; somewhat complex; needs to be reliable; time is not an issue and the schedule visibility is somewhat important?

02.58.question: Micah is a fairly new project manager. He estimated for a project plan (on the planning phase) that the project would cost $50,000 and take 20 weeks. According to the margin of error guidelines for well-done estimates, that could range from:

02.59.question: Extreme Programming (XP) is BEST characterized as:

02.59.A.choice: A method for exploring design alternatives

02.59.B.choice: A method for emphasizing customer satisfaction

02.60.question: Which of the following is NOT a classic planning mistake?

02.60.A.choice: Adding people to a late project

02.61.question: The science (or art) of project management is setting a schedule and sticking to it no matter what – even if that includes working weekends and adding staff to reach the deadline on time.

02.62.question: The Throwaway Prototyping methodology is good at creating release version 1.0 for users; and then the methodology shifts to system prototyping to finish the system.

02.63.question: What the MAIN difference between systems prototyping and throwaway prototyping?

02.63.A.choice: Throwaway prototyping develops systems that will be use as 'stop-gap' systems – and generally for less than six months; while systems prototyping results in systems that will be used extensively for several years.

02.63.B.choice: Throwaway prototyping involves users while systems prototyping does not

02.63.C.choice: Systems prototyping works with users to quickly develop a simplified working version of the proposed system; while throwaway prototyping focuses more on exploring design alternatives

02.63.D.choice: Systems prototyping is a rapid application development methodology; while throwaway prototyping is not

02.63.E.choice: Systems prototyping involves users while throwaway prototyping does not

02.64.question: Project estimates tend to have a built-in buffer of time

02.65.question: Which of the following methodologies might be most appropriate if you have a system project with: clear requirements; very familiar technologies; not all that complex; reasonably reliable; a short time schedule and the schedule visibility is not important?
